creator: jph@us.ibm.com
text:
The company I work for uses an automated security program to scan ports
and probe programs to detect security exposures.  This program has recently
been enhanced and now complains about a "security exposure" in the standalone
HTTP server included with Tomcat.  Specifically, it sends this HTTP request:

POST / HTTP/1.0
Content-Length: %s%s%s%s%s%s%s%s%s

(with an extra \r\n on the end to denote an empty body)

The idea here is to test for a badly-written C program the uses the given
string as a printf() pattern string (see http://julianor.tripod.com/tn-usfs.txt
for more information on these types of programs).

Tomcat reacts to this request by closing the socket, giving no response.  The
security program interprets this as a failure; it presumes it managed to crash
the server.  The security program is, of course, misinterpreting the result.
Tomcat does not crash.  Nevertheless, it seems to me that Tomcat should be
responding with "400 Bad Request" instead.  If the security program receives
any response at all, the server "passes" the test.

I know this is a nit, but it would be very helpful to me if it were fixed.
I haven't tried this on Tomcat 4.
